Recovery Document Objectives: Safeguard existing populations and if feasible introduce to unoccupied habitat with aim of increasing population size by 50%.
Species Data: Likely less than 100 mature individuals in 2 locations
Rationale: Currently not possible to determine population trends for this species.

Recovery Document Objectives: Maintain presence in each known occurrence.
Species Data: Probably less than 1000 mature individuals.
Rationale: Population trends cannot be determined from the available data.

Recovery Document Objectives: Maintain the Canadian population at its current known size, distribution and area of occupancy.
Species Data: The population is estimated at 410 000 to 1 063 000 stems, distributed in 18 subpopulations. The subpopulations appear to be stable.
Rationale: Populations are stable

Recovery Document Objectives: Maintain current population density and area of occupancy.
Species Data: Population estimated to be 1 080 000 to 9 360 000 individuals. Subspecies distributed in 3 distinct subpopulations in 3 separate dune fields. Potential decline in extent of occurrence based on forest ingress along western margins of William River dunes. Decline in habitat due to net conversion of open dune area to forest.
Rationale: No information available to directly assess population trends

Recovery Document Objectives: By 2015, conserve the genetic characteristics of the few remaining anadromous inner Bay of Fundy Atlantic salmon populations. Re-establish self-sustaining populations to their conservation levels in 10 river systems.
Species Data: This population once bred in 32 rivers tributary to the inner Bay of Fundy; however, spawning no longer occurs in most rivers. The population, which is thought to have consisted of about 40 000 individuals earlier in the 20th century, is believed to have been fewer than 200 individuals in 2008. Survival through the marine phase of the species' life history is currently extremely poor, and the continued existence of this population depends on a captive rearing program.
Rationale: Fewer than 200 mature individuals are left in the wild and the population is not self-sustaining.

Recovery Document Objectives: Not feasible
Species Data: n/a
Rationale: n/a

Recovery Document Objectives: Achieve stability in the current population in Nova Scotia. Re-establish the anadromous (ocean-going) form. Increase the number and range of viable populations.
Species Data: Qualitative information indicates that the population has declined in recent decades and that abundance in the Petite Rivière watershed is low. This species, present in only a single location, is restricted to 3 interconnected lakes and a dam prevents access to the sea. The extent of occurrence has remained unchanged. Hatchery-reared fish have been released on an experimental basis and survival of hatchery fish in 1 lake has been confirmed in subsequent years.
Rationale: Individuals have been introduced to suitable watersheds in order to expand the species' range.

Recovery Document Objectives: Increase the population levels and distribution in eastern Canadian waters and ensure long-term viability of the species.
Species Data: The species has been increasing in abundance and area of occupancy since the mid-1990s. While these recent increases are encouraging, the species remains at low abundance compared to historical levels.
Rationale: There are signs of population recovery.

Recovery Document Objectives: Maintain at least 11 of the known populations in Yukon. Prevent a decline in the extent of occurrence.
Species Data: Population trends at all but the Carcross dune systems have probably remained roughly stable or declined slightly in recent years. Numbers have probably declined more substantially at the Carcross dunes. There is an observed continued decline in the extent of occurrence and number of locations.
Rationale: The number of mature individuals, the extent of occurrence and the number of locations have declined.

Recovery Document Objectives: Maintain known populations in British Columbia.
Species Data: Population trends are unknown.
Rationale: Population trends are unknown.

Recovery Document Objectives: Maintain existing population levels and distribution.
Species Data: No data are available with regard to population trends. A single population estimate, for the Indian Bay watershed site with 12 529 to 40 201 individuals, is the only abundance data available. Populations at Loch Leven and Freshwater Pond have been described as abundant. Although data are limited, there is no indication of decline in either the number of populations or abundance within populations.
Rationale: Population appears to be stable. No indication of decline in either the number of populations or abundance within populations.

Recovery Document Objectives: Restore self-sustaining snail populations and habitat within historic range, where and when possible. The Recovery Strategy was amended in Nov 2010. No changes were made to the recovery goals established in 2007.
Species Data: These short-lived animals undergo natural annual fluctuations of over 2 orders of magnitude. There are no historical records of snail population levels. Reintroductions made in 2002 and 2003 appear to be self-sustaining. When the 2 reintroduced subpopulations are added to the original 5 populations, there is a significant increase in the population.
Rationale: All subpopulations remain and appear stable but there seem to be an observed decline in total population.

Recovery Document Objectives: To see positive growth and promote the long-term viability of a naturally-producing population.
Species Data: The early historic and scientific record for Basking Sharks is limited but consistently describes the Pacific population of Basking Shark as abundant and widely spread, with a minimum historic population of 750 individuals off the coast of British Columbia. At present, Basking Sharks appear infrequently in Canadian Pacific waters. There were 36 confirmed or reliable Basking Shark sightings reported from 1996-2016.
Rationale: Population trends are unknown.

Recovery Document Objectives: Maintain or enhance the 7 existing populations, increasing smaller ones. Establish 1 experimental population with an average annual population size of at least 300 flowering individuals.
Species Data: The estimated number of plants is between about 4000 and more than 100 000, reflecting the difficulty of estimating population sizes for this species. The number of plants varies from year to year and trends cannot be determined.
Rationale: Due to a lack of reliable counts and the sizeable fluctuations in the number of mature individuals, current population trends cannot be determined.

Recovery Document Objectives: Maintain all 8 existing populations or subpopulations at no less than their current levels of abundance. Restore at least 2 extirpated populations or establish at least 2 new populations.
Species Data: When assessed in 2015, the population was estimated at about 2 900 mature individuals in 9 extant subpopulations. Only 1 subpopulation is large. Habitat information suggests there has probably been a decline. The subpopulation at Cattle Point has been lost since 2001.
Rationale: There has probably been a decline in the size of the total population. One subpopulation has been lost.

Recovery Document Objectives: Increase the population size to 7070 individuals, or 70% of its historical size.
Species Data: Since the early 2000s, the population has declined slowly, with an estimated total population of 889 in 2012. The population has declined by 12.6% in the last 10 years. Reasons for this decline are not understood.
Rationale: The population has been declining and reasons for this decline are not understood.

Recovery Document Objectives: Establish a wild population of black-footed ferrets that has at least an 80 percent probability of persisting for 20 years.
Species Data: The species was reintroduced to Grassland National Park in 2009, with subsequent releases in 2010-2012. Although the reintroduction demonstrated many successes, a concurrent decline observed in the Black-tailed Prairie Dog population as a result of unknown factors led to the suspension of releases in 2013.
Rationale: Reintroduction demonstrated many successes.

Recovery Document Objectives: Maintain, or enhance, existing populations and improve the quality and quantity of their associated habitats.
Species Data: A population estimate is not available, but the population appears to be stable. Capture records since the 1970s do not suggest a decline in abundance, although direct comparison is complicated by a broader sampling effort.
Rationale: Canadian population appears to be stable.

Recovery Document Objectives: Ensure the population maintains at least a 90% probability of persistence for the next 100 years.
Species Data: A monitoring program has been implemented to measure population densities, area occupied and occurrence of sylvatic plague. The area occupied by Black-tailed Prairie Dogs has fluctuated but all colonies remain active. There is no data on population trends.
Rationale: No data on population trends. Species status was changed from Special concern to Threatened.

Recovery Document Objectives: Determine if the Blanchard's Cricket Frog is still present in its Canadian range Determine whether suitable habitat for reintroduction still exists.
Species Data: The species is known in Canada from only at a single site on Pelee Island: Fish Point Provincial Nature Reserve. Over the last 2 decades, observations and auditions have been reported sporadically from Fish Point, including 1 as recently as 1997. Unfortunately, none of these more recent reports are supported by photographs or audio recordings of calling frogs. The lack of confirmed reports, coupled with the relatively small size of Fish Point and the short lifespan of individual frogs has led a number of authors to suggest that it has been extirpated from Canada.
Rationale: No new sightings of this species in Canada have been recorded.

Recovery Document Objectives: Achieve a self-sustaining population over the current Nova Scotia range. Maintain or increase recruitment and adult survivorship.
Species Data: The slow life-history of this long-lived species means that this population has not yet recovered from mortality occurring decades ago. However, recovery efforts have increased the number of young turtles in the main population.
Rationale: Adult numbers have continued to decline but recovery efforts have increased the number of young turtles.

Recovery Document Objectives: Reach a population size of 1000 mature individuals.
Species Data: A total of 16 Blue Whales were sighted during a 2007 Department of Fisheries and Oceans survey. Too few sightings were obtained to derive an estimate of abundance but the low number of sightings is consistent with previous estimates suggesting there are fewer than 250 mature individuals. No trend has been evident. A total of 402 individual blue whales have been identified in the Gulf of St. Lawrence between 1980–2008. It is unclear whether they were mature individuals or not. An 11% yearly increase in sightings was documented in the Gully over the 23-year period.
Rationale: The population is estimated to contain fewer than 250 mature individuals; however further data on changes in population size is needed to determine if progress has been made.

Recovery Document Objectives: Attain a long-term viable population of Blue Whales that use Pacific Canadian waters. Long-term goals must span several generations, and therefore have a horizon of 150–300 years.
Species Data: A handful of photo-identified Blue Whales in British Columbia and the Gulf of Alaska indicate the potential re-establishment of historic feeding grounds. What is believed to be Blue Whale foraging behaviour has primarily been observed in late summer and fall in Washington and British Columbia waters. That seasonal presence is consistent with recently recorded acoustic data, but direct observations from ship-based visual surveys and historical records show their occurrence in Pacific Canadian waters from late spring through late summer.
Rationale: The relative proportion of Blue Whales is yet unknown because of the limited number of observations gathered since commercial whaling ceased.

Recovery Document Objectives: Maintain the three self-sustaining populations (Summit Lake, Upper and Lower Boundary Creek Ponds) and, if feasible, to restore the extirpated population (Carthew Pond).
Species Data: Monitoring shows a steady, increasing population at Summit Lake and Lower Boundary Pond. Monitoring of Upper Boundary Pond indicates a decrease in cover but an increase in presence at sample locations.
Rationale: The three existing populations have been maintained.

Recovery Document Objectives: Maintain thalli and habitat at sites where Boreal Felt Lichen is known to occur.
Species Data: Eleven of the 41 occurrences found between 2003 and 2011 are now extirpated. These declines are projected to continue in the future.
Rationale: Both the number of occurrences and number of individuals are declining. Available habitat has declined between 1988 and 2005.

Recovery Document Objectives: Maintain and enhance where necessary, self-sustaining populations within the species' current geographic distribution.
Species Data: Increases are occurring in some areas, and declines in others. Conclusions about trends are complicated by the discovery of many thalli in new areas as a result of increased search effort.
Rationale: It is not clear whether observed increases at some sites offset the declines observed at other sites.

Recovery Document Objectives: Maintain and enhance populations and their habitats, to ensure that viable populations are present throughout the species' current and historic range in Canada.
Species Data: Population sizes have not been estimated in Canada, and trends are difficult to determine due, in part, to difficulties in species identification. It has been found at many new locations, likely due increased identification of the species rather than an increase in range.
Rationale: Population sizes have not been estimated in Canada.

Recovery Document Objectives: Maintain habitat at Craigflower Meadow site while feasibility of population restoration is assessed. Establish and/or augment populations to increase abundance and distribution 4 if determined to be feasible and biologically appropriate for Brook Spike-primrose.
Species Data: No individuals have been found at either of the two sites since 1993. Possible viable seeds are in the soil and may germinate when conditions are right.
Rationale: No individuals have been found at either of the two sites since 1993

Recovery Document Objectives: Maintain the persistence of all naturally occurring populations in Canada.
Species Data: The size of each Buffalograss clone fluctuates with changes in moisture and nutrients, expanding when availability is high and contracting when it is low. The population is now known to be considerably larger than was estimated in 1998, likely reflecting increased survey effort. Whether Buffalograss in Canada has been spreading or declining is unknown.
Rationale: Population trends in Canada are unknown.

Recovery Document Objectives: Reverse population declines. Maintain a self-perpetuating, well-distributed population of at least 3000 breeding pairs. Re-establish wild breeding populations in British Columbia and Manitoba.
Species Data: Populations declined from at least 795 individuals in 2004 to 270 in 2015. A few owls from captive breeding and release programs in British Columbia and Manitoba have been sighted in the wild.
Rationale: Populations are declining but owls have been reintroduced to previous parts of their range.

Recovery Document Objectives: Ensure conditions that will allow for the restoration of viable, ecologically functioning, and broadly distributed populations within its current range.
Species Data: Butternut populations may not be currently viable due to high rates of infection and mortality caused by the butternut canker. Restoration requires disease-free butternut stands or trees. At present, the conditions required to achieve and ensure disease-free populations are unknown.
Rationale: n/a

Recovery Document Objectives: Maintain populations at their current abundance and distribution within the Whitemouth, Birch and Winnipeg river systems.
Species Data: There is no evidence to date that populations have suffered any serious decline in abundance or distribution over time. However, there is a projected decline in population over the next 10 years. The COSEWIC status changed from Threatened in 2006 to Endangered in 2018.
Rationale: The population appears to be stable.

Recovery Document Objectives: Maintain existing populations in Ontario and Quebec and restore self-sustaining populations to formerly occupied habitats, where feasible.
Species Data: The Channel Darter is found at low abundances throughout its range, and evidence suggests that abundances are generally declining throughout the Canadian range of the species.
Rationale: Populations are likely declining.

Recovery Document Objectives: Ensure the long-term viability of the population in the wild. Maintain, and where possible enhance, the ecological integrity of habitat.
Species Data: The abundance is unknown. Trends in indices of abundance suggest a persistent decline from 1975 to 2004.
Rationale: The species appears to have declined in abundance.

Recovery Document Objectives: Ensure long-term viability across its extant distribution in the wild.
Species Data: The historic distribution in Canada is assumed to be similar to its present-day distribution, but habitat alterations from flow regulation have been significant in the Columbia and Kootenay Rivers, and it is possible that historic distribution differed.
Rationale: Through the implementation of several conservation actions, progress has been made towards achieving the management goal of ensuring long-term viability of Columbia Sculpin in British Columbia.

Recovery Document Objectives: Maintain known populations.
Species Data: Detailed population data do not exist; new occurrences have been located and some may be extirpated.
Rationale: Detailed population data do not exist.

Recovery Document Objectives: Maintain populations in 7 core areas. Ensure that the number of mature individuals does not decline below 1000 and where feasible, increase smaller populations that are currently considered unviable.
Species Data: Population trend is unknown but, within sites where subpopulation data are available, the number of mature individuals appears to have increased by approximately 200%. Numbers at 9 sites are increasing, 3 sites were extirpated, 34 sites lack trend information, 11 previously undocumented sites were recorded and 2 of the 3 sites identified as extirpated in 2002 were rediscovered.
Rationale: Some subpopulations have increased, some were extirpated and previously undocumented sites were recorded.

Recovery Document Objectives: Halt the national decline by 2025, while ensuring the population does not decrease more than 10% over this time. The long-term objective is to ensure a positive 10-year population trend. Maintain the current extent of occurrence.
Species Data: The population has declined by 68% between 1970 and 2015, but the rate of decline has slowed appreciably to 12% over the 10-year period (2005-2015). The species appears to be quite abundant in suitable boreal habitats.
Rationale: Decline has slowed in the past decade. The species appears to be abundant in suitable habitats.

Recovery Document Objectives: Attain a population of 4000 mature individuals by 2032.
Species Data: The Copper Redhorse is known from only 3 locations, 1 of which is extirpated. Since the mid-1980s, the population has declined significantly. The total number of mature individuals appears to be several thousand at the most, but the population is aging and there are very few young individuals. Virtually no juveniles have been caught in the last 30 years. An artificial reproduction and stocking program was implemented in 2004, but it is too early to draw conclusions about its success.
Rationale: No increase in population abundance and 1 location has been extirpated.

Recovery Document Objectives: Goal is to maintain all known extant populations of Cryptic Paw Lichen in British Columbia. Objectives: habitat protection, inventory suitable habitat, mitigate threats and clarify population demographics and establish monitoring protocols
Species Data: Total subpopulations from habitat-based estimates are for the Interior BC 1,351 thalli, Northwestern BC 2,294 thalli and Coastal BC 7,557 thalli. Projected decline of at least 30% over 60 years
Rationale: Projected trends in habitat loss and edge effects project a decline of more than 30% in 60 years

Recovery Document Objectives: By 2012, protect existing natural populations and their habitats. By 2032, increase population size to 50 reproductive individuals in at least 2 sites within each of 2 regions.
Species Data: Overall, populations appear to be at a steady state, with several sites showing increases and some decreases. The estimated number of canopy trees (excludes saplings and seedlings) has increased from fewer than 50 trees in 1984, to 186 in 1998?2001, to 188 in 2008.
Rationale: Ontario populations appear to be at a steady state. Large trees have increased in number.

Recovery Document Objectives: Maintain current population numbers and prevent any further loss of populations or distribution.
Species Data: In 2012, population size in Canada was estimated to be 14?000 individuals in 3 population centres. This is a decrease from 2002, when the population size was estimated between 28?500 and 40?500 individuals in 3 or 4 populations.
Rationale: Population has declined.

Population Name: Great Lakes - Western St. Lawrence populations
Recovery Document Objectives: Ensure the long-term persistence of Deepwater Sculpin throughout its current and historical distribution in the Great Lakes – Western St. Lawrence DU.
Species Data: Population estimates for Deepwater Sculpin in Canada are not available. Outside of efforts in the Great Lakes (predominately in American waters), Deepwater Sculpin has not been sampled extensively in a standardized manner and, hence, estimating population sizes and trends is not possible at this time.
Rationale: Population sizes have not been estimated in Canada.

Recovery Document Objectives: Maintain existing populations at their current levels of abundance or greater. Restore Deltoid Balsamroot to its approximate historical extent of occurrence and area of occupancy and establish at least 2 new self-sustaining populations.
Species Data: In 2007 there were 1589 plants in Canada that were large enough to flower. Most populations appear to be relatively stable since 1996. However, the largest population declined from a peak of about 1700 plants in 1992 to 345 plants in 2007, as a result of commercial development of the site. The sharp decline at this site accounts for most of a 35 to 40% decline in the total Canadian population since 1996.
Rationale: There is a sharp decline in the total Canadian population.

Recovery Document Objectives: Not feasible
Species Data: Extirpated 1968.
Rationale: n/a

Recovery Document Objectives: Protect and maintain extant populations at current or greater levels of abundance with no reduction of current range. Improve conditions and enhance populations at occupied sites.
Species Data: The number of mature individuals is estimated to be less than 9000 within 2 populations (18 subpopulations); note these plants grow closely together in patches and individuals are difficult to distinguish. The area occupied in the larger population has declined due to gull nesting and tree and shrub incursion. Some sites cannot be relocated and may have disappeared. Eight new sites found since 1985 likely represent new information rather than newly occupied sites. Overall, 1 population is in decline, the other appears relatively stable.
Rationale: Overall, 1 population has declined, the other appears stable.

Recovery Document Objectives: Maintain the number of microsites (345) in Point Pelee National Park over the next 5 years and increase total number of microsites by 5% over the next 10 years. Maintain population size (5 microsites) at Fish Point Provincial Nature Reserve on Pelee Island over the next 5 years.
Species Data: At Fish Point, the 5 microsites continue to persist as of 2013, a follow-up survey will be completed in 2018. Surveys were completed for Point Pelee National Park in 2005 and 2015-2017, however the results are not yet available.
Rationale: Trends cannot be determined.

Recovery Document Objectives: Maintain populations at known locations. Achieve a self-sustaining population with a 95% probability of persistence across its current range. Maintain or expand the current distribution of wetlands used by Eastern Ribbonsnakes in southwestern Nova Scotia.
Species Data: There is limited evidence that some populations may be declining in parts of Nova Scotia. Eastern Ribbonsnakes appear to have disappeared from 1 site in Nova Scotia, which in the 1980s contained the highest known density of these snakes in the province. The known extent of occurrence has increased considerably, due to increased search efforts.
Rationale: Long-term population trends could not be established. There is limited evidence that some populations may be declining.

Recovery Document Objectives: Maintain self-sustaining, extant populations and to restore self-sustaining populations to formerly occupied habitats where feasible.
Species Data: For the first time, Eastern Sand Darter has been detected in the Detroit River. Furthermore, sampling conducted within West Lake, Prince Edward County by the Ontario Ministry of Natural Resources and Forestry (OMNRF) has led to the first detection of Eastern Sand Darter within the Lake Ontario watershed.
Rationale: Targeted sampling is required to generate robust quantitative estimates of Eastern Sand Darter population sizes in order to set meaningful population and distribution objectives.

Recovery Document Objectives: The objective over the longer term (i.e., 20 years) is to promote the growth of existing populations to ensure their viability and, wherever possible, to restore historical populations that have disappeared.
Species Data: In Québec, trends in Eastern Sand Darter populations are largely unknown due to a lack of recent sampling in several river systems.
Rationale: The lack of records despite recent sampling in Rivière Châteauguay suggests that the Eastern Sand Darter may have declined in this river. New locations have recently been discovered in Rivière Ouareauof the L'Assomption drainage, Missisquoi Bay of Lac Champlain in the Richelieu drainage, and Rivière aux Saumons. It is not possible to assess trends in five Québec rivers due to lack of recent sampling.

Recovery Document Objectives: Maintain the species' distribution within Canada.
Species Data: The population has declined as a result of a 2011 terrain slumping event in Grassland National Park that killed and displaced snakes from the largest known den of this subspecies in Canada.
Rationale: The population has declined since 2011.

Recovery Document Objectives: Establish captive populations of the Enos Lake species pair. Establish or recover a viable population of the Enos Lake species pair, preferably in Enos Lake.
Species Data: Since at least 1994, the distinctions between benthics and limnetics as assayed using genetic and morphological techniques have declined dramatically such that genetically pure forms of both species are thought to no longer exist and have been replaced by hybrids. The estimated total population size of sticklebacks is on the order of at least 20 000 mature individuals. Without further massive sampling and analytical efforts, it is impossible at present to disprove the idea that some “genetically pure” benthics and limnetics may remain within Enos Lake. There are no pure Enos Lake Benthic Threespine Sticklebacks in captivity.
Rationale: It is unlikely that genetically pure benthics remain in Enos Lake and no captive populations have been established.

Recovery Document Objectives: Establish captive populations of the Enos Lake species pair. Establish or recover a viable population of the Enos Lake species pair, preferably in Enos Lake.
Species Data: Since at least 1994, the distinctions between benthics and limnetics as assayed using genetic and morphological techniques have declined dramatically such that genetically pure forms of both species are thought to no longer exist and have been replaced by hybrids. The estimated total population size of sticklebacks is on the order of at least 20 000 mature individuals. Without further massive sampling and analytical efforts, it is impossible at present to disprove the idea that some “genetically pure” benthics and limnetics may remain within Enos Lake. Enos Lake Limnetic Threespine Sticklebacks exist at another site, but these appear to have diverged from the parent population.
Rationale: It is unlikely that genetically pure limnetics remain in Enos Lake and a captive population appears to be different.

Recovery Document Objectives: Maintain or restore a self-sustaining, wild population across its historical range by 2036.
Species Data: Recent results, when compared to historical trapping records, suggest a decline in numbers.
Rationale: A historical population decline since the 1950s is inferred.

Recovery Document Objectives: Recovery is not feasible for this species at this time. Determination of recovery feasibility will be re-evaluated in response to changing conditions and/or knowledge (that is, if Eskimo Curlews are located).
Species Data: Dramatic declines in numbers were observed in the 1870s to 1890s, after which Eskimo Curlews became very rare. No nests have been reported for over 100 years, despite extensive surveys in historical breeding areas. Although there have been a number of sightings reported in recent decades, mostly during migration, there have been no fully substantiated records since 1963, when a bird was collected in Barbados.
Rationale: n/a

Recovery Document Objectives: Maintain current population density and area of occupancy.
Species Data: Population estimated to be 2 340 000 to 37 070 000 individuals. Potential decline in extent of occurrence based on forest ingress along western margins of William River dunes. Decline in habitat due to net conversion of open dune area to forest.
Rationale: No information available to directly assess population trends

Recovery Document Objectives: Maintain populations within the current species range.
Species Data: A survey between 1996 and 2000 estimated that there were 3434 flowering Fernald's Braya. The same 15 populations counted 8–12 years later contained only 1242 mature plants (a 64% decline). An additional population not known during the first survey (Green Island Brook) contained 2056 mature plant. However, the Green Island Brook population occurs in a site disturbed by human activity and may only persist by immigration from outside populations. The population size of Fernald's Braya continues to decline, based on permanent monitoring plots.
Rationale: Population size is declining.

Recovery Document Objectives: The objective of the present management plan is to ensure that anthropogenic threats in Canadian waters do not provoke a decline in the population or a reduction in the currently observed Canadian range.
Species Data: Fin Whale abundance in the North Atlantic and North Pacific appears to be recovering following severe depletion from commercial whaling in the 20th century.
Rationale: Although no abundance trend is available for the Canadian Pacific, surveys in neighbouring US waters show increasing abundance at an annual average of 7.5% off the US mainland west coast and 4.8% off Alaska.

Recovery Document Objectives: Attain a population viable in the long term that uses Canadian Pacific waters.
Species Data: Currently sighted only infrequently. Whaling took thousands of animals through the 1970s. Based on the severe depletion and lack of sufficient time for recovery, it is inferred that present population is below 50% of its level, 60–90 years ago.
Rationale: Population trends are unknown.

Recovery Document Objectives: Maintain current population density and area of occupancy.
Species Data: Population estimated to be 2 780 000 to 21 380 000 individuals in the core Athabasca sand dunes complex. Potential decline in extent of occurrence based on forest ingress along western margins of William River dunes. Decline in habitat due to net conversion of open dune area to forest.
Rationale: No information available to directly assess population trends

Recovery Document Objectives: Maintain the size and distribution of currently known extant populations.
Species Data: Trends in the Canadian range or abundance cannot be assessed, owing to the scarcity of historical data. Increased search efforts have increased the number of known occurrences to 76. A former occurrence at Wawa is extirpated.
Rationale: One location has been extirpated.

Recovery Document Objectives: Maintain and/or increase sufficient suitable habitat to support a metapopulation (20-30yrs)
Species Data: Species has not been observed since 1988.
Rationale: Species has not been observed since 1988.

Recovery Document Objectives: Maintain the 2 known Nova Scotia occurrences, as well as any other populations that are discovered in Nova Scotia.
Species Data: Increased survey effort has found this species at additional sites. Although habitat availability is thought to be declining, no known sites have been lost.
Rationale: Known occurrences have been maintained.

Recovery Document Objectives: By 2020, maintain the existing populations at a minimum of 200 individuals per segment in river segments between Grand Falls and Perth Andover, maintain the number of individuals at a minimum of 250 between the International border and Grand Falls, and maintain the number of individuals at a minimum of 250 at the upland site near Aroostook. By 2020, establish self-sustaining populations in additional river segments within its range.
Species Data: Available data suggests relative stability in population numbers from 1977 to 2002, followed by possible declines between 2001–2002 and 2008–2010. Because of its dynamic habitat and poor competitive ability, local extinctions and colonization events are expected over time. Since 2003, monitoring at known sites, through restricted scope, suggest that the population may still be in decline. Changes to river dynamics, land clearing of buffer trees, recreational activities, and the introduction of invasive species have resulted in continuing population decline at the existing sites.
Rationale: Populations continue to decline at existing sites.

Recovery Document Objectives: Maintain or increase the distribution in Canada.
Species Data: The number of occupied sites appears to be relatively stable, but likely has declined from historical levels due to habitat loss. There are too few data for useful population estimates.
Rationale: There is insufficient information to determine population trends, although habitat continues to decline.

Recovery Document Objectives: Attain viable, self-sustaining populations distributed throughout its historic range in Canada. Achieve a minimum of at least 9 populations, maintaining the 2 existing populations at their current levels of abundance, and establishing at least 7 new populations.
Species Data: Golden Paintbrush has been reported from 8 locations in Canada, only 2 of which have extant populations. Based on the most recent data there was a total of 3361 flowering plants in Canada in 2006. This appears to represent a population decline of about 25% over the past 10 years.
Rationale: Decline in population size is inconsistent with goal of attaining self-sustaining populations at existing sites. No new populations have been established.

Recovery Document Objectives: Maintain extant populations at present levels of abundance or greater.
Species Data: The total Canadian population includes hundreds of thousands of rosettes, although the number of genetic individuals is certainly much lower. Populations occur near lakes and are almost certainly slowly declining with shoreline development.
Rationale: Population size is declining slowly.

Recovery Document Objectives: Ensure the long-term persistence throughout its distribution in Canada. Maintain and increase existing populations.
Species Data: There is likely a decline in the population size of 3 of the 13 subpopulations. In 2014, a sub-population was confirmed to exist in Quebec where it was last detected in 1988. The current range remains lower than the long-term historical records.
Rationale: There is a decline in the abundance within 3 subpopulations and the range has also decreased.

Recovery Document Objectives: Confirm that gravel chub is no longer present, examine habitat conditions, threats and feasibility of reintroduction.
Species Data: Gravel Chub was not detected but permission to survey an important site was not received.
Rationale: n/a

Recovery Document Objectives: No loss of numbers or active leks in any portion of the current Canadian range (a lek is a traditional area where males congregate in spring to compete for mates). By 2012, all populations show a positive trend in the number of strutting males at leks and the number of active leks. By 2026, achieve a stable or increasing population with at least 865 strutting males at leks, and at least 46 active leks.
Species Data: Greater Sage-Grouse populations in Canada appear to be cyclic; however, inconsistent monitoring between years and provinces make it difficult to assess these cycles and annual rates of change. The overwhelming trend appears to be one of decline. From 1988 to 2006, the total Canadian population declined 88%.
Rationale: Population and number of occupied leks are in decline.

Recovery Document Objectives: Maintain populations in all of the critical habitat polygons within the 8 currently known areas of occupancy of the species plus any new populations discovered in the future
Species Data: Current trends in population size and habitat quality is unknown. Some subpopulations are presumed extirpated near Medicine Hat. Surveys have noted increases and decreases in subpopulations, however presence of lizards have not been confirmed in areas near Medicine Hat.
Rationale: Recent declines are evident in local areas, particularly around Medicine Hat (subpopulations presumed extirpated).

Recovery Document Objectives: Not feasible
Species Data: n/a
Rationale: n/a

Recovery Document Objectives: Maintain the current known distribution, and migration route of Grey Whales in Pacific Canadian waters.
Species Data: n/a
Rationale: n/a

Recovery Document Objectives: Maintain or increase population sizes at all 10 existing locations. Where feasible, reintroduce the species to previous locations with suitable or capable habitat.
Species Data: In November 2001, 4 populations (3 recent, 1 historic) were known. Twelve additional populations had been located by November 2011. One population has become extirpated recently with a minimum loss of 1 colony. Thus, 15 populations are confirmed extant and 1 is extirpated, for a total of 16 populations. One population appears to be declining. Currently, 9 populations appear to be stable and trends for the 5 most recently discovered populations are unknown. The current abundance estimate totals 1173 mature individuals (colonies).
Rationale: Currently, 9 populations appear to be stable; trends for the 5 most recently discovered populations are unknown.

Recovery Document Objectives: Maintain a self-sustaining population within its known range in Pacific waters of Canada.
Species Data: There are no systematic survey data or population trends. A population of 9120 porpoises was estimated during 2004 and 2005 in British Columbia coastal waters (excluding west coast of Vancouver Island and Haida Gwaii).
Rationale: Population trends are unknown.

Common Name: Harbour Seal Lacs des Loups Marins subspecies
Recovery Document Objectives: The distribution objective of this strategy is to maintain the present range of the Lacs des Loups Marins Harbour Seal.
Species Data: There are no reliable estimates of the abundance of Lacs des Loups Marins Harbour Seals because little information is available. Range-wide abundance trends cannot presently be calculated.
Rationale: Population trends are unknown.

Recovery Document Objectives: Maintain a wintering population of 3000 Harlequin Ducks in eastern North America for 3 of 5 consecutive years.
Species Data: An estimated 3226 to 3420 Eastern population adults winter along the east coast of North America. All birds from this wintering population originate from Canadian breeding areas. Though still small relative to historical levels, this wintering population has increased since cessation of hunting in 1990. The population trend from 1981 to 2013 for birds wintering in eastern North America is estimated to be increasing at about 5% per year.
Rationale: Population size is increasing, and appears to have met the population levels outlined in the goals.

Recovery Document Objectives: Maintain extant populations at their current abundance and distribution.
Species Data: The Canadian population is estimated to be more than 110 000 individuals. Abundance was not calculated in the past, so it is not possible to know if there has been any change.
Rationale: Population trends are unknown.

Recovery Document Objectives: By 2015, to achieve at least 1 stable breeding population of 5 to 10 pairs. The recovery strategy was amended on 15 September 2010. No changes were made to the recovery goals established earlier in 2010.
Species Data: The abundance and breeding distribution of the Henslow's Sparrow have undergone marked fluctuations in response to changes in habitat availability. Observations since 1985 are too few to determine recent trends. There are no indications of any increase for the period 2000 to 2011.
Rationale: Data are too few to determine recent trends.

Recovery Document Objectives: Increase size of existing populations to self-sustaining levels.
Species Data: No decline in mature individuals is documented, and owing to new discoveries, the population now includes more than 250 individuals. There are 2 populations of this species known to be extant. An additional subpopulation was newly discovered in 2010, and appears to have become established from an existing seed bank following site restoration initiated in fall 2008. At the time of assessment it contained 15 seedlings.
Rationale: Population sizes are not sufficiently well documented to indicate trends.

Recovery Document Objectives: Increase the number of breeding pairs to 500, distributed within the species' current Ontario range.
Species Data: Data from all sources show a consistent pattern of strong increases in the abundance and distribution of the population in Canada. The Canadian population in 2013 is estimated to be between 500 and 1000 breeding pairs. Searches at known and potential breeding locations documented ongoing increases in population size, number of occupied sites, and breeding distribution.
Rationale: Increasing population has reached recovery goals.

Recovery Document Objectives: Maintain and protect the population(s) within its natural geographic range and within its current range of abundance.
Species Data: Hotwater physa occurs in 3 definable areas. Additional surveys are required to assess the population trend but the current evidence does not indicate a decline in the population. As of 2008 populations appeared to be stable, with seasonal fluctuations. Potential increases were observed from 2008 to 2013, but inconsistent methodology and low sample sizes make comparisons difficult. The trend remains unclear.
Rationale: Although populations fluctuate widely, there appears to be no change to abundance or distribution.

Recovery Document Objectives: Recovery of this species is considered not technically or biologically feasible at this time. Determination of recovery feasibility will be re-evaluated in response to changing conditions and/or knowledge.
Species Data: No change. There has been no change in the documented size of, or trends in, the Canadian population.
Rationale: n/a

Recovery Document Objectives: Confirm the presence of the subspecies within its historic range in Canada, and protect any extant populations.
Species Data: This species has not been documented in the field since 1979. However, search effort is insufficient to conclude that the species is extinct.
Rationale: n/a

Recovery Document Objectives: Attain viable, self-sustaining populations within the species' historic range in Canada.
Species Data: This butterfly was formerly found on 2 islands off the west coast, but disappeared from both sites by 1910 because of loss of the larval host plant. The historic Canadian range of the Island Marble has been extensively surveyed since 2001 in an effort to locate it along with other at-risk butterflies. During these surveys, neither the Island Marble nor apparently suitable habitat has been detected. All available evidence suggests that the Island Marble is extirpated in Canada.
Rationale: Available evidence suggests the Island Marble is extirpated in Canada.

Recovery Document Objectives: Maintain and/or increase sufficient suitable habitat to support a metapopulation (20-30yrs)
Species Data: Species has not been observed since 1991.
Rationale: Species has not been observed since 1991

Recovery Document Objectives: Maintain healthy self-sustaining populations in the Ausable and Sydenham rivers while returning the Lake St. Clair delta population to a self-sustaining level. Re-establish populations in historically occupied habitats.
Species Data: The Kidneyshell is now Extirpated in upper and lower Thames and Grand Rivers and in Lake Erie off Pelee Island. Currently, the species is restricted to the East Sydenham and Ausable rivers, Lake St. Clair delta, and Medway Creek of the Thames River. Populations continue to decline in Lake St. Clair and Ausable River, while populations in the Sydenham River appear stable. Both Ausable and East Sydenham river populations appear to be reproducing but populations in Medway Creek and Lake St. Clair are not reproducing. The extent of occurrence declined to 2050 square kilometres in 2001, but has subsequently increased to 2866 square kilometres over the last 10 years, largely due to increased search effort.
Rationale: Although populations in the Sydenham River appear stable, populations continue to decline in Lake St. Clair and Ausable River.

Recovery Document Objectives: Maintain current population sizes at or above the current level. Maintain number of breeding females at levels that will provide a neutral or positive growth rate. Attain the long-term viability of the population.
Species Data: This population has approximately 122 mature individuals. The population has been increasing since the mid-1970s when monitoring began, due to intrinsic growth and immigration. Since 1990, population growth has slowed due to reduced immigration.
Rationale: The population has been increasing.

Recovery Document Objectives: Achieve and maintain demographic conditions that preserve reproductive potential, genetic variation, and cultural continuity.
Species Data: This population has been increasing slowly since monitoring began in 1975. There are 290 animals in the population as of 2015 and it is considered to be stable or increasing.
Rationale: Population trend is increasing or stable.

Recovery Document Objectives: Achieve and maintain demographic conditions that preserve reproductive potential, genetic variation, and cultural continuity.
Species Data: The population is small and has declined since the mid-1990s. As of 2015, there are 84 animals in the population. The population is currently considered to be stable.
Rationale: Only 84 animals in the population, with a stable trend.

Recovery Document Objectives: Determine if a breeding population exists in Canada. Manage habitat at selected locations in Canada to encourage the recovery of the species.
Species Data: This species has been recorded in Canada almost annually since 1990. In Michigan, the stronghold of the species range, the population increased from a low of 167 singing males in 1974 to 1479 in 2006. Singing males in suitable breeding habitat have been recorded sporadically, and breeding has been confirmed twice, most recently in 2007 at CFB Petawawa.
Rationale: There have been signs of a breeding population in Canada.

Recovery Document Objectives: Maintain current populations and restore viable populations to formerly occupied wetland habitats.
Species Data: Canadian collections have not been made in a standardized manner, nor have there been specific studies on population size, making it difficult to assess population sizes and trends; however, the paucity of records suggests low abundance.
Rationale: It is difficult to establish viable population and distribution objectives in the absence of detailed population records; therefore, further monitoring and assessment should be conducted to refine the extent of the species’ distribution and determine its prevalence within its current distribution.

Recovery Document Objectives: Maintain current population density and area of occupancy.
Species Data: Population estimated to be 910 000 to 6 950 000 individuals. Potential decline in extent of occurrence based on forest ingress along western margins of William River dunes. Decline in habitat due to net conversion of open dune area to forest.
Rationale: No information available to directly assess population trends

Recovery Document Objectives: Increase the population such that the long-term viability of the leatherback turtles frequenting Atlantic Canadian waters is achieved.
Species Data: The size of the seasonal foraging population in Canada is not known, but sightings data suggest that it numbers in the thousands in Atlantic waters. Most major western Atlantic nesting populations may be stable or increasing slightly. Trends from nesting beaches known to or most likely to contribute to the population found in Canadian waters are used as proxies.
Rationale: The population appears to be stable or slightly increasing.

Recovery Document Objectives: Achieve the long-term viability of the leatherback turtle population(s) that frequent Pacific Canadian waters.
Species Data: Sightings in Pacific Canadian waters are sparse and the number of turtles using these waters is not known. The beaches from which they likely originate have had their numbers of nesting females reduced by more than 90% in recent decades. Most nesting colonies in the Pacific are in steep decline, falling as much as 95% in less than 1 generation.
Rationale: Nesting colonies in the Pacific are in a steep and continuing decline.

Recovery Document Objectives: Maintain the current size and distribution of the population in Canada.
Species Data: Population trends are poorly understood. The species has declined locally in parts of Canada in the past century and in the past few decades, but surveys have found higher numbers in some parts of the Canadian range in recent years.
Rationale: Declines have been noted in some parts of the Canadian range, while new pairs have been found in others.

Recovery Document Objectives: Maintain current population density and area of occupancy.
Species Data: Population estimated to be 3 040 000 to 25 000 000 individuals. Potential decline in extent of occurrence based on forest ingress along western margins of William River dunes. Decline in habitat due to net conversion of open dune area to forest.
Rationale: No information available to directly assess population trends

Recovery Document Objectives: Confirm presence in Canada. Protect and maintain any extant populations.
Species Data: No change. This moss is a large, showy species that occurs just above water's edge along small montane streams. A rare North American endemic, its northernmost and single occurrence in Canada is in southern British Columbia. Although the species was not relocated at this station in recent surveys, the species may be present in nearby watersheds.
Rationale: No new sightings of this species in Canada have been recorded.

Recovery Document Objectives: Maintain or improve the recent (since 1996) population and distribution in Canada.
Species Data: The species declined by at least 30% between 2002 and 2012.
Rationale: There has been a continuing decline in the number of individuals.

Recovery Document Objectives: Ensure the conservation of the Monarch butterfly migratory phenomenon. By 2020, 6 hectares of overwintering habitat in Mexico occupied.
Species Data: Population size estimates are not available for Canada. The overwintering population in Mexico, as measured by area of occupied habitat, declined significantly between 1994 and 2015. Four hectares of habitat were occupied in 2015.
Rationale: It is too early to assess progress towards objectives.

Recovery Document Objectives: Map habitat, find any additional colonies, determine population size, start stewardship activities.
Species Data: Designated Threatened in May 2003. Status re-examined and designated Special Concern in May 2014.
Rationale: n/a

Recovery Document Objectives: Maintain recent abundance and distribution.
Species Data: No more than 11 birds have been recorded in Canada within one year. This species may not consistently breed in Canada. An increase in records during the last 30 years may be due to increased search effort in later years.
Rationale: Long-term trends cannot be established with existing data.

Recovery Document Objectives: By 2015, all currently and historically suitable habitats in native streams to be occupied at target abundance levels.
Species Data: Insufficient data exist to reliably calculate population sizes.
Rationale: Population trends are unknown.

Recovery Document Objectives: Achieve an increasing trend in population abundance over 3 generations.
Species Data: Between 2009 and 2014, the population estimate increased from 438 to 522. The population increased by about 50% between 1990 and 2010.
Rationale: Population has increased from 1990 to 2014.

Recovery Document Objectives: Work towards an increasing population trajectory. Promote reoccupation of historical habitat in Pacific Canadian waters.
Species Data: Presence was confirmed in Canada in 2013. Numbers in the eastern North Pacific are extremely small (less than 50 individuals). There is no data on the population trend.
Rationale: Population trends are unknown.

Recovery Document Objectives: By 2012, halt the decline of the existing wild population. By 2037, increase number and densities to self-sustainable levels in each biogeographic zone of British Columbia.
Species Data: Since the fisheries closure, total abalone density estimates have been fluctuating at low levels and there have been no statistically significant changes. Poaching is the most serious threat and continues to reduce population abundance, particularly the larger animals; however, all size classes have declined significantly over the past 3 generations with mature individuals declining an estimated 88 to 89%. The densities of mature abalone in each of the out-planting sites have remained below objectives.
Rationale: There has been no evidence of population recovery since the fishery closed in 1990.

Recovery Document Objectives: Achieve a stable or increasing population. Maintain or extend current distribution.
Species Data: This well-studied population contains an estimated 164 individuals, of which approximately 93 are mature. The population appears to be stable but it is very small and at risk from entanglement in fishing gear and possibly also from anthropogenic noise and from exposure to contaminants.
Rationale: The population appears to be stable and there has been no decline in the area of occupancy.

Recovery Document Objectives: Sustain and enhance the viability of existing populations of Northern Madtom in the Erie-Huron corridor, the Thames River (from Littlejohn Rd. upstream to vicinity of Tate Corners), and the Sydenham River if the species is still present in the system.
Species Data: Ongoing and/or completed activities indicate that progress is being made toward the goal of recovering Northern Madtom populations in Canada
Rationale: The recent environmental DNA (eDNA) detections of Northern Madtom within the Sydenham and Grand rivers warrants follow-up sampling to confirm the species presence within these watersheds.

Recovery Document Objectives: Return healthy self-sustaining populations to 5 previously occupied locations (Ausable, Grand, Sydenham and Thames rivers and the St. Clair River delta).
Species Data: The Northern Riffleshell once occurred in 6 locations, but it now appears restricted to the Ausable and Sydenham rivers. The Sydenham River population may have had serious declines in the 1970s and 1980s, but recruitment is now occurring at several sites. This perceived recovery could be an artifact of intensive and increased sampling effort over the past 12 years. The Ausable River population was only discovered in 1998 and since then only 16 live animals have been found.
Rationale: The trends are consistent with early recovery: the Northern Riffleshell is found in the Sydenham and Ausable rivers, and recruitment is occurring at several sites in the Sydenham River.

Recovery Document Objectives: Maintain approximately 1800 adults over the species' extent of occurrence.
Species Data: The current population estimate is of 1756 mature individuals with a inferred decline of 1.3% over the next 15 years.
Rationale: Population sizes and trends have not been measured directly but projected trends in habitat loss suggest a potential decline in population size.

Recovery Document Objectives: Increase the population levels and distribution such that the long-term viability of this species is achieved.
Species Data: This species underwent strong declines in both abundance and in range size during the 1980s. For the next decade there was little change in status, but since about 2002 there have been small increases in both range size and abundance.
Rationale: There have been early signs of recovery in distribution and abundance.

Recovery Document Objectives: Maintain the only known extant population of this species at its location in Canada. Maintain or improve current population size at this location, as well as any other extant populations that may be identified.
Species Data: This species is known from only 3 localized sites in south-central British Columbia. One of the sites has likely been extirpated and one has not been seen since 1980.
Rationale: One subpopulation persists but the number of mature individuals is uncertain.

Recovery Document Objectives: Maintain a stable or increasing population, distributed throughout the species' current range in British Columbia.
Species Data: The species has a restricted range in the South Okanagan and Similkameen valleys. These habitats have been in decline since the mid-1800s and habitat loss is expected to continue. The number of mature individuals is unknown.
Rationale: The number of mature individuals is unknown.

Recovery Document Objectives: Short term objective is to stop the national decline by 2025 and limit the decline to 10% during this time. Long term objective (after 2025) is to have a 10-year increasing population trend. The distribution objective is to maintain the current extent.
Species Data: Estimates from different sources suggest that the population may be relatively stable or may be declining by as much as 19% over a 10-year period.
Rationale: Boreal Avian Modelling Project does not provide evidence of a decline in population between 1997 and 2013. Breeding Bird Survey estimates an annual decline of 2.1% from 2006 to 2016.

Recovery Document Objectives: Maintain stable populations in British Columbia.
Species Data: Although the population suffered large-scale declines associated with overharvest between the late 1800s and 1930, it appears to have been stable in recent decades. There are no data on population trends, but populations appear to persist at low levels.
Rationale: Although quantitative estimates on population sizes are not available, the Olympia Oyster appears to be stable in recent decades.

Recovery Document Objectives: Ensure that self-sustaining populations continue at currently occupied sand hill areas in southeastern Alberta and in southwestern Saskatchewan.
Species Data: Annual population monitoring in Alberta has revealed a 72% decline in abundance between 2006 and 2015. This is assumed to be representative of the entire Canadian population.
Rationale: Population size is declining.

Recovery Document Objectives: Determine if Ottoe skippers are still extant in Canada.
Species Data: n/a
Rationale: n/a

Recovery Document Objectives: Maintain the known extant populations and supporting habitat. Increase the number and distribution of populations within the species' natural range.
Species Data: Too few individuals have been captured to allow population trends to be assessed.
Rationale: Population estimates are not available.

Recovery Document Objectives: Not feasible
Species Data: n/a
Rationale: n/a

Recovery Document Objectives: Maintain persistence of Pale Yellow Dune Moth at confirmed localities.
Species Data: Insufficient data to assess population sizes and trends. Historical sites have likely declined due to habitat loss from vegetation ingrowth and dune stabilization.
Rationale: Habitat is in decline as sand dunes stabilize with vegetation

Recovery Document Objectives: Maintain self-sustaining populations of stickleback species pairs in Paxton Lake.
Species Data: Limnetics and benthics are locally abundant, and not in apparent decline; the primary factor determining conservation status is their extreme endemism (existing in a single location), not population decline.
Rationale: Benthics appear to be stable and locally abundant in Paxton Lake.

Recovery Document Objectives: Maintain self-sustaining populations of stickleback species pairs in Paxton Lake.
Species Data: Limnetics and benthics are locally abundant, and not in apparent decline; the primary factor determining conservation status is their extreme endemism (existing in a single location), not population decline.
Rationale: Limnetics appear to be stable and locally abundant in Paxton Lake.

Recovery Document Objectives: Maintain a self-sustaining population of the Peregrine Falcon anatum/tundrius throughout its Canadian range for the next 10 years.
Species Data: All subpopulations have increased (except Labrador which saw a 5% decrease in documented territories) during the latest 20 year survey periods (either 1990 to 2010 or 1995 to 2015). Lack of recovery in the Okanagan Valley continues to be a concern.
Rationale: Subpopulations have increased with the highest numbers seen in 2010 and 2015 surveys.

Recovery Document Objectives: Maintain extant populations at present levels of abundance or greater at current locations. Restore habitats to re-establish populations.
Species Data: The Canadian population is believed to have remained relatively stable within the past 10 to 15 years, with minor declines (less than 2.2%) due to shoreline development. The increased estimate of population sizes in 2012 is almost certainly due to more systematic and comprehensive surveys. Surveys repeated at particular sites over many years have not produced any anecdotal reports of major declines or increases.
Rationale: The Canadian population is relatively stable; estimates have increased due to increased survey effort.

Recovery Document Objectives: Establish at least 3 populations across its historic range, including the extant Clo-oose Bay population by 2015.
Species Data: Restoration efforts have been successful at two of four sites and it is currently not possible to conclude that any sub-populations that have been established should be considered viable over the long term.
Rationale: In 2017, recovery efforts are successful at only two sites.

Recovery Document Objectives: Support and augment international efforts to restore and increase populations.
Species Data: n/a
Rationale: n/a

Recovery Document Objectives: Maintain a minimum of 1626 adult Piping Plovers (813 pairs) during each of 3 consecutive international censuses (i.e., over 11 years) in the Prairie Canada population. The Recovery Strategy was amended on 13 Aug 2007. No changes were made to the recovery goals established in 2006.
Species Data: Counts from the most recent International Piping Plover Census in 2011 indicate an overall Canadian population of approximately 1033 adults of the interior subspecies. The count may be an underestimate because flooding in 2011 reduced available habitat and forced nesting pairs into areas not included in the census. However the consistent flooding since the last census suggests that reduction in population size is expected. Information on population trends for the interior subspecies shows a long-term (1991 to 2011) decline of 22.9% and a short-term decline of 12% over 2001 to 2011.
Rationale: Population is less than the short-term population goal and declining.

Recovery Document Objectives: Short term: Achieve and maintain a regional population of 255 pairs and an annual productivity of 1.65 chicks fledged per territorial pair. Long-term: Increase the population to 310 pairs distributed across eastern Canada.
Species Data: The 2011 International Piping Plover Census estimated an overall Canadian population of approximately 406 adults. The annual surveys available for the eastern subspecies indicate a population of 389 adults in 2013. Information from annual surveys shows a significant decline of 23% between 2003 and 2013.
Rationale: Population is less than the short-term population goal and declining.

Recovery Document Objectives: Maintain extant populations at present levels of abundance or greater at current locations. Restore habitats to re-establish populations.
Species Data: Available survey data are insufficient for direct assessment long-term trends, however, populations appear to have been relatively stable between 1984 and 2011. Available evidence suggests that the overall population trend for Canada over the past 15 years is likely a minor decline of less than 2%.
Rationale: Relative stability is consistent with maintenance of populations, yet a minor decline may have occurred.

Recovery Document Objectives: Protect and maintain the extant population.
Species Data: Poor Pocket Moss occurs in only 1 site. In 2000, only 1 colony was found. By 2009, a total of 6 colonies were observed in the original location in 2009 and an additional small colony was found nearby.
Rationale: Poor pocket moss now occupies more patches but the original patch is smaller than previously.

Recovery Document Objectives: Maintain or increase the number of sub-populations and colonies. Where feasible, re-establish to known historic locations.
Species Data: Currently, of 33 habitat patches, 79% have fewer than 50 individuals and 52% have fewer than 20 individuals, which is less than the minimum genetically effective population size of 50. In Alberta and Newfoundland, provinces that contain the majority of all known subpopulations, trends show a loss of approximately 17 colonies.
Rationale: Where trends data is available (Alberta and Newfoundland), there was an overall decline of 28% in the number of colonies over the last three generations.

Recovery Document Objectives: Ensure a self-sustaining population within and surrounding the Tall Grass Prairie Preserve, distributed within an area similar to that found in surveys.
Species Data: Population size estimates are unavailable but a decline is suspected. The area of occupancy has changed little since 2002.
Rationale: Population decline is uncertain, area of occupancy is stable.

Recovery Document Objectives: Manage and enhance the single extant population. Establish additional populations. One additional population (2 sub-populations) has been confirmed since recovery goals were set.
Species Data: The species was known historically from 9 populations but only 2 populations are confirmed as extant. Consistent sampling has not been done for a long enough period to determine trends in population size and density. There is no evidence overall decline from 1999 to 2009. The new subpopulations found recently were likely always present. One population may now persist in the seed bank.
Rationale: No evidence of total population decline has been observed, and 1 additional population was discovered.

Recovery Document Objectives: Recover the Canadian population to at least 40 breeding pairs spread among at least 6 distinct nesting areas. By 2015, increase the current population to at least 15 pairs, spread among at least 5 nesting areas.
Species Data: Numbers have remained stable or declined slightly from an estimated 28–34 mature individuals in 2005 to 28 in 2015. In Canada, breeding habitat is continuing to deteriorate due to invasive species.
Rationale: While the rate of decline has slowed, the 2015 population objective was not met.

Recovery Document Objectives: Confirm the presence/absence of Puget Oregonian Snail within the species' historic range. Protect any extant population(s) if found.
Species Data: No change. Extensive searches within the historical range have failed to find the species.
Rationale: No new sightings of this species in Canada have been recorded.

Recovery Document Objectives: Maintain, or enhance, existing populations, and improve the quality and quantity of associated habitat by 2029.
Species Data: The sizes of Canadian populations are unknown and existing evidence is insufficient to determine trends in population numbers. There is evidence of continuing decline in extent of occurrence and quality of habitat. The Thames River population has been lost and possibly the MacDougall Drain population (last observed in 1984). New populations have been confirmed in Whitebread Drain.
Rationale: There is evidence of continuing decline in extent of occurrence and the quality of habitat.

Recovery Document Objectives: Maintain self-sustaining populations at existing locations. Restore self-sustaining populations to historic locations where feasible.
Species Data: Population sizes are not known in Canada. The known area of occupancy has increased since 2002, likely due to increasing knowledge of the distribution of the species, rather than expansion by the species itself. The species' numerous small populations may not be viable and habitat degradation and loss continues to occur.
Rationale: Population trends are not available.

Recovery Document Objectives: The recovery of the pygmy short-horned lizard in Canada is not considered technically and biologically feasible. This may be revisited if relict populations are discovered, and/or if translocation and reintroduction becomes feasible and appropriate.
Species Data: Confirmed occurrences include 2 specimens. Last reliable sighting in 1957.
Rationale: n/a

Recovery Document Objectives: Maintain presence of existing populations at all sites where they are currently known to occur and conserve new occurrences that are identified.
Species Data: Insufficient data to determine population sizes
Rationale: There is insufficient data available to determine population trends.

Recovery Document Objectives: Maintain the current population distribution and abundance of the small-bodied and large-bodied populations of Lake Utopia Rainbow Smelt and the genetic diversity of the Lake Utopia Rainbow Smelt sympatric species pair.
Species Data: Based on samples conducted from 1998 to present, the population abundance of the Lake Utopia sympatric pair appears fairly consistent from year to year.
Rationale: The high abundance of Small Smelt spawners and their apparent restriction to only a few of the available tributaries may indicate that the lake itself is at maximum carrying capacity, at least for the Small Smelt (Curry et al. 2004).

Recovery Document Objectives: Return/maintain healthy self-sustaining populations to the Sydenham and Thames rivers and St. Clair River delta.
Species Data: In Canada, the Rayed Bean occurs only in Ontario where its range once included the Detroit, Sydenham and Thames rivers and western Lake Erie. The current distribution is restricted to the Sydenham River and a short reach of the North Thames River. A lack of historical records prevents an estimate of population change. However, there appears to be a much larger population in the Sydenham River than documented prior to 2000; the numbers found recently could not have been overlooked in historical studies.
Rationale: The population in the Sydenham River appears to have increased.

Recovery Document Objectives: Prevent extirpation of the percna subspecies from the island of Newfoundland. Support a self-sustaining population.
Species Data: Populations still remain in Newfoundland but are declining and habitat loss is expected.
Rationale: Populations are declining.

Recovery Document Objectives: Maintain all currently existing populations of the species across its Canadian (Ontario) range and prevent further decline in the number of individuals.
Species Data: The total known Canadian population is 217 individuals. The number of mature individuals has declined 6.3% since 2000 despite ongoing discovery of new trees at some sites. Three of 19 subpopulations appear to have been extirpated since 2000.
Rationale: Population size and distribution are declining.

Recovery Document Objectives: Maintain viable, self-sustaining, ecologically functioning and broadly distributed populations within suitable habitats in its current distribution/range in B.C.
Species Data: Population information on the Rocky Mountain Ridged Mussel is unknown and densities likely vary depending on habitat suitability and quality, with lower quality habitat supporting lower mussel densities.
Rationale: Further efforts will be necessary to meet the management goal of maintaining viable, self-sustaining, ecologically-functioning and broadly-distributed populations of Rocky Mountain Ridged Mussel in British Columbia.

Recovery Document Objectives: By 2014, have no fewer than 150 pairs of Roseate Terns nesting in at least 3 colonies in Canada. Enhance productivity at managed colonies. Restore a broader distribution by establishing at least 1 more managed colony. The Recovery Strategy was amended in 2010. No changes were made to the recovery goals established in 2006.
Species Data: The 2007 population estimate for Canada was 200 mature individuals occupying 7 locations (approximately 98% are in only 2 locations). The number of mature birds has been fairly stable over the past decade despite recovery efforts.
Rationale: Population of 100 pairs below population goal with no increasing trend.

Recovery Document Objectives: Return healthy self-sustaining populations to the Sydenham River and Lake St. Clair delta. Re-establish populations in historically occupied habitats.
Species Data: Between 2003 and 2013, Round Hickorynut is estimated to have declined between 75% and 95% as populations in the Sydenham River and Lake St. Clair have declined to levels near extirpation. Approximately 55 000 mature individuals were reported in Lake St. Clair in 2001, and the 2013 population was estimated at 825 to 13 750 mature individuals. No mature individuals were found alive during surveys in the Sydenham River between 2002 and 2009, except for 1 in 2012. The 2013 extent of occurrence is 120 square kilometres, which represents a decline of 92% since 2001.
Rationale: Round Hickorynut declined between 2003 and 2013; extent of occurrence has declined since 2001.

Recovery Document Objectives: Prevent the extirpation of the Round Pigtoe in Canada. Return healthy self-sustaining populations to the Sydenham, Thames and Grand rivers and the St. Clair Delta.
Species Data: The species occupies a small zone, with continuing declines in habitat area, extent and quality. Numbers of live individuals found were lower in 3 sites. In the Grand River, the number of live individuals found had increased but these individuals were large/old animals and the increase was likely due to an increase in search effort.
Rationale: There has been a decline in the area, extent and quality of habitat and an apparent decrease in the number of live individuals.

Recovery Document Objectives: Stop the population decline by 2025. In the longer term, demonstrate a sustained increase.
Species Data: Since 1970, the population has declined 85 to 90%. However, the population has been fairly stable between 2004 and 2014.
Rationale: Declines appear to have levelled off.

Recovery Document Objectives: Maintain or improve population sizes for the 6 known extant populations in Canada, as well as any other populations that may be identified.
Species Data: Rusty Cord-moss is now known from 17 sites, most of which are small. Resurveyed subpopulations appear stable, but many sites with small subpopulations could not be relocated in 2015, making it difficult to estimate trends.
Rationale: Population sizes appear stable. Some sites with a few individuals may have disappeared.

Recovery Document Objectives: Prevent the extirpation of the Salamander Mussel in Canada. Return/maintain healthy self-sustaining populations to the Sydenham and Thames rivers and St. Clair River delta.
Species Data: The Salamander Mussel appears to be restricted to the East Sydenham River in Canada, where 17 live animals were found at 4 different sites during extensive surveys in 1997 to 1999. Although the data are few, there is no evidence that the population in the Sydenham River is declining. Habitat quality continues to decline from intense agriculture, urban development, and pollution from point and non-point sources.
Rationale: Habitat quality continues to decline and the species is currently found in only 1 river.

Recovery Document Objectives: Maintain current population density and area of occupancy.
Species Data: Population estimated to be 4 240 000 to 90 500 000 individuals. Potential decline in extent of occurrence based on forest ingress along western margins of William River dunes. Decline in habitat due to net conversion of open dune area to forest.
Rationale: No information available to directly assess population trends

Recovery Document Objectives: Increase the size of the 4 known extant subpopulations and establish 1 additional subpopulation in Canada.
Species Data: Five sites are recorded in British Columbia, 2 of which are new since the initial assessment. Population numbers are not well known, therefore a change their numbers cannot be reported. A reduction can be inferred based on cumulative habitat losses at all sites.
Rationale: Population numbers are not well-enough known to assess change.

Recovery Document Objectives: Maintain the breeding population at the current level.
